Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Medium: Collaborative Research: GOALI: Adaptive and Flexible Spectrum Optical Networking

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will study and develop technology for Elastic Optical Networks (EONs). In EONs flexible amounts of spectral bandwidth may be allocated to each data channel without requiring adherence to a fixed wavelength grid. Such an approach is well-suited for supporting a wide range of dynamic traffic demands in a bandwidth-efficient manner. Key enabling technologies, optical arbitrary waveform generation
(OAWG) and optical arbitrary waveform measurement (OAWM), will enable elastic optical networking over a large spectrum by dividing the spectrum into spectral slices and dynamically processing information at lower rates compatible with CMOS electronics. The project will leverage these technologies as a basis for innovative hardware and software solutions for EON technology, architectures, protocols, network control and management, system integration, and testbed integration.

Advances in the basic architecture and technology for optical networking is important for US competitiveness. The project will work with several US-based industrial organizations as a means of technology transfer. The research results and publications will likely to impact standardization activities of flexible grid networking (e.g. International Telecommunication Union ITU-T SG15 on flex grid). The project will link education and research and serve as a rich platform for crossdisciplinary education in optical and higher-layer networking, and in computer engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project made significant advancements in the field of autonomous, high-bandwidth, and cognitive elastic optical networking (EON) with comprehensive studies related to novel transceivers technologies and architectures, protocols, network control and management, system integration, performance monitoring and cognitive tools for automated network performance optimization. The more significant impacts achieved across the entire project duration include:

(1)   Demonstration of novel digital signal processing techniques for enhancing the performance of flexible bandwidth transmission systems,

(2)   novel static and dynamic allocation of network and spectral resources to meet user demands in a cost-effective and spectrally-efficient manner,

(3)   new approaches for provisioning protection resources in EONs,

(4)   traffic grooming and defragmentation techniques for improving the utilization of spectral resources in EONs,

(5)   novel optical performance monitoring techniques necessary for cross-layer QoS-aware and impairment-responsive networking,

(6)   novel hierarchical network control and management plane with cognitive functionalities for automated optimization of EONs,

(7)   application of emerging machine learning techniques for optical networks optimization problems.

 

The cross-fertilization of ideas from multiple disciplines covering software defined optical networking, cognitive networking, optical technologies, distributed control theory, machine learning, and game theory provided a rich environment for (1) students to learn leading-edge science and tools, and (2) for the faculty members to create forward-looking curricula in multidisciplinary graduate and undergraduate level programs.

The scientific results obtained during the course of this project have been disseminated through more than 20 publications at major international peer-reviewed conferences and journals. These studies and related results allowed the students and faculty members to have better understanding of the underlying issues in the performance and scalability requirements of optical networks to sustain the ever-increasing demand of information exchange in nowadays modern society and social networking.
